holdings.text: The judgment of the Revenue Court in Suit No. 15 of 1939 does not operate as res judicata in the present suit because the Revenue Court was not competent to try the present suit under Section 11 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, it is not necessary to consider the differences between thescope of the priniciple of res judicata covered by s. 11 of the Code

holdings.reasoning_summary: Present suit for title declaration not within exclusive jurisdiction of revenue courts under Agra Tenancy Act s.230 and Fourth Schedule; s.11 CPC requires former court competent to try subsequent suit.

holdings.text: There was a partition of the larger family of Lachhman Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: On the whole, on a consideration of the material placed before us, we cannot say that the finding given by the learned Civil Judge and accepted

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption of jointness rebutted by direct evidence and course of conduct over 50 years: separate living, cultivation, mutations in revenue records, absence of disputes, Kashi Ram's will treating properties as self-acquired.

holdings.text: There was no reunion between Kashi Ram, Raghubar Dayal and Bhagwan Dayal.

anchor.surface_text: From this conduct, spreading over about 50 years, it is not possible to hold that the uncle and the nephews consciously entered into an agreement

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reunion requires strict proof of intention to reunite in estate and interest, express or implied unambiguously from conduct; here conduct consistent with co-tenancy/partnership, contradicted by documents like will, adoption deed asserting self-acquisitions, mutations in widow's name.

holdings.text: Kashi Ram (uncle) and Raghubar Dayal and Bhagwan Dayal (nephews from different branch) did not hold jointly acquired properties as joint family property; such members cannot form a coparcenary unit; properties pass by inheritance, not survivorship.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Coparcenary is creature of Hindu (Mitakshara) law, not created by agreement (except reunion); only full family or branch constitutes corporate unit capable of holding JFP with birth/survivorship; different branches/some members of branch hold as co-sharers governed by contract.

holdings.text: Kashi Ram's properties were self-acquired, validly bequeathed by will to nephews as co-tenants.

The holding that the Revenue Court's judgment does not operate as res judicata is grounded in CPC Section 11's requirement that the former court be competent to try the suit.
CPC Section 11 directly addresses the issue of res judicata applicability in subsequent suits, focusing on matters in issue in prior suits by competent courts.
The procedure under Section 271 where revenue court refers title issues and accepts civil findings grounds the holding that the revenue court lacked competency for res judicata effect

The Agra Tenancy Act Section 271 describes revenue court referring title issues to civil court, directly addressing the issue of whether revenue court judgment based on civil findings operates as res judicata
